published_attributes.title: Intro
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Better gear up guys! Here's what we gonna learn in this chapter:

  • First contact with the client
  • Consulting approach
  • Expert Calls
  • Proposal calls
  • Estimation process

published_attributes.title: Communication tips
published_attributes.serialized_body:
General rules

  • Be active, not passive - recommend solutions
  • Listen to the expectations of the client, don’t be afraid to ask
  • Consult your solutions with developers from day one
  • Make sure to explain how to use communication tool (eg. comments in Invision, eventually explain difference about tour-points and comments)

Feedback

  • Does the client have time to give you feedback?
    • If not try to ask for active stakeholders that can actively participate in the communication.
  • Make the client aware of the value of an active and collaborative approach (feedbacks, communication)
  • Make sure that there is only one final point of feedback from the client side
  • Make sure that have the opportunity to present your solutions to all of the stakeholders.
  • Make sure that client knows that we don’t work in the fixed number of reviews but in constant feedback and iteration mode.

blocks.text: General rules

Listen to the expectations of the client, don’t be afraid to ask
Consult your solutions with developers from day one
Make sure to explain how to use communication tool (eg. comments in Invision, eventually explain difference about tour-points and comments)
Feedback

If not try to ask for active stakeholders that can actively participate in the communication.
Make the client aware of the value of an active and collaborative approach (feedbacks, communication)
Make sure that there is only one final point of feedback from the client side
Make sure that have the opportunity to present your solutions to all of the stakeholders.
Make sure that client knows that we don’t work in the fixed number of reviews but in constant feedback and iteration mode.

published_attributes.title: Communication tips
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Previous experience

  • Does the client work with the designers before?
    • If not, try to educate him to design good practices and basic principles during your meetings.
    • If yes, what are the experiences of the client working with the designers?
  • Does the client understand the role of the designer?

Milestones & priorities

  • Make sure that the client has a reasonable approach for the making an MVP (keeping the scope small)
  • Make the client aware of the importance to go step by step in terms of functionalities.

Why it is important to sell the outcomes of your work

  • By selling well yourself or your work, you gain client’s trust in your decision.
  • When you hesitate, don’t know the “whys” behind your design decision you scare clients.

blocks.text: Previous experience

If yes, what are the experiences of the client working with the designers?

Make the client aware of the importance to go step by step in terms of functionalities.
Why it is important to sell the outcomes of your work

When you hesitate, don’t know the “whys” behind your design decision you scare clients.

published_attributes.title: Communication tips
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Must haves while communicating with a client

  • Know the benefits and outcomes of your work.
  • Gain client’s trust - then they will care about your opinions
  • Often your client’s future depends on you, your decisions and your work. Everything you do serves to convince them.
  • Don’t ask the basic questions that can be easily found in Google.
  • Every decision you make must match the business goals of your client - always and foremost.
  • You can use structure:
  • [What you did]  + [how you come up with the thing you did]  + [why you did it / how this will help client’s business]
  • Avoid mythical users - First and foremost care about the client’s business. Our clients often have no users and the limited amount of money.
  • There are no maybe's, there is confidence -be absolutely sure about your statements
  • Tell about “whys” of your design and how it increases their business’ chances to succeed.
  • Don’t talk about the things the client can see on their own. Say it this way: “This element is placed here because it will help X achieve/with Y”
  • Use data -When you assume something, base it on good practices, behaviour studies, statistics.
  • It’s much better to present a small number of great arguments than flood the client with dozens of mediocre ones
  • Adjust your language - don’t use jargon

blocks.text: Must haves while communicating with a client
Know the benefits and outcomes of your work.
Gain client’s trust - then they will care about your opinions
Often your client’s future depends on you, your decisions and your work. Everything you do serves to convince them.
Don’t ask the basic questions that can be easily found in Google.
Every decision you make must match the business goals of your client - always and foremost.
You can use structure:
[What you did]  + [how you come up with the thing you did]  + [why you did it / how this will help client’s business]
Avoid mythical users - First and foremost care about the client’s business. Our clients often have no users and the limited amount of money.
There are no maybe's, there is confidence -be absolutely sure about your statements
Tell about “whys” of your design and how it increases their business’ chances to succeed.
Don’t talk about the things the client can see on their own. Say it this way: “This element is placed here because it will help X achieve/with Y”
Use data -When you assume something, base it on good practices, behaviour studies, statistics.
It’s much better to present a small number of great arguments than flood the client with dozens of mediocre ones
Adjust your language - don’t use jargon

published_attributes.title: Explaining the Design Process
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Introduction

We have many people around projects. Most of them would highly benefit from having a check-up on the business perspective of the product they are working on. And there is also a no better way to assist our client in business decisions and work as a consultant than to understand product’s business environment, its competitors, advances and life cycle.

Strategy should be a first stage of taking over projects from Sales and as such should be connected to client information Sales has about the client. It is not meant to be an overall new analysis of the business plan, rather gathering information mostly from Sales on the first stage, secondly from Client and basic market research.

published_attributes.title: Explaining the Design Process
published_attributes.serialized_body:
The most important aspects

  1. Client: the specification of a company (or client himself if it’s individual); it's business objectives for next months; plans towards product and expectations following its launch; place of the future product in the company’s structure; budget issues. This research is already a part of handover from sales and kick off/ quarterly call with Client about their business objectives so nothing new to be added at that point except gathering all information in one place.
  2. His business
  3. His market: it’s important to understand the local market where the product is about to be launched as there are extreme differences between each country market’s needs and/or requirements (ex. Projects from strict Muslim countries will have much more limitations regarding teams than the ones from Europe). Also, geography determines business values and market needs to be fulfilled by the product. This stage is extremely important, yet often underestimated. This information can also be taken from the Client, as most of them know at least the most important objectives of market their product is about to enter. It can be deepened by personal research of project PM or PM responsible for Product Research in certain cases.
  4. His competition: with the biggest focus put on local market of the Client, global market concerning only in cases of big projects to be promoted globally; competition analysis should include at least 2 biggest competitors of our Client, their competitive advantages regarding features and business values. Competition analysis will differ regarding product and project. Competitors are often marked by a Client during the kick-off. If not, it’s worth asking or searching by PM/designer (if is in the project).
  5. His product: the business objectives behind investment; why does client want to create the product. What is the business model? What is their go to market strategy? Who will be the first users? This information is also to be taken from the Client during the kick-off of the project or quarterly call.
  6. His users
  7. Needs/expectations towards Netguru: sometimes Clients expect some special treatment: they need similar to the Netguru’s side or otherwise, plan the outsourcing only. Additional business/upsell opportunities could also be included in this part. This part will be for Netguru only, not to be shared with the Client.

This information is also to be taken from the Client during the kick-off of the project or quarterly call.
His users

Needs/expectations towards Netguru: sometimes Clients expect some special treatment: they need similar to the Netguru’s side or otherwise, plan the outsourcing only. Additional business/upsell opportunities could also be included in this part. This part will be for Netguru only, not to be shared with the Client.

published_attributes.title: Explaining the Design Process
published_attributes.serialized_body:
When to iterate

  • Every time when a project comes back to Netguru
  • After changing some important features
  • After changing any of the important factors (details about Client, product strategy etc.)
  • If nothing above: update every 6 months.

blocks.text: When to iterate
Every time when a project comes back to Netguru
After changing some important features
After changing any of the important factors (details about Client, product strategy etc.)
If nothing above: update every 6 months.

published_attributes.title: Explaining the Design Process
published_attributes.serialized_body:
How to explain the design process to the client

Educate Client

  • Product design is a process. The process includes iterations that will result in the improvements of the product or service. The final iteration is complete when the client’s goals and the users’ goals are achieved.
  • The design is about how things work, not only about how they look.
  • Educate the client about your role and your expectations. Establish the boundaries and expectations at the beginning. Useful links: What to expect from a designer | What are you paying for | Designer-Client relationship

blocks.text: How to explain the design process to the client
Educate Client

Product design is a process. The process includes iterations that will result in the improvements of the product or service. The final iteration is complete when the client’s goals and the users’ goals are achieved.
The design is about how things work, not only about how they look.

Educate the client about your role and your expectations. Establish the boundaries and expectations at the beginning. Useful links: What to expect from a designer | What are you paying for | Designer-Client relationship

published_attributes.title: Explaining the Design Process
published_attributes.serialized_body:
How to explain the design process to the client

Avoid multi-platform design at the early stages of the project

  • If the client needs a multi-platform design, ask another designer for help. If you believe that the scope is big enough, always suggest a design team. Learn more from: Why a Team Approach Is the Key to Successful Product Design

Emphasize that it’s impossible to predict users’ behaviour accurately

  • We rely on the research and available data – the validity of a solution can only be assessed with relevant tests.

We cannot guarantee a business success

  • Try to make it clear that even the best product design does not guarantee a product’s success in terms of revenue.

published_attributes.title: Strategy questions
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Introduction

This article consists of an explanation of how to gather insights from the client before starting cooperation with him/her. It consists of chapters that explain when to use the strategy questions, how to use it, what are the tools and expected output of this stage. In the end, you can find the real use cases and related links for those of you, who would like to get to know more about the process.  The most important part of this document is the list of questions. This list is also linked to the separate page, that is treated as a template, available for copying and sending to the client. Gathering insights (answers on questions listed below) should precede the work on the design.

Gathering insights (answers on questions listed below) should precede the work on the design.

blocks.text: Introduction

This article consists of an explanation of how to gather insights from the client before starting cooperation with him/her. It consists of chapters that explain when to use the strategy questions, how to use it, what are the tools and expected output of this stage. In the end, you can find the real use cases and related links for those of you, who would like to get to know more about the process.  The most important part of this document is the list of questions. This list is also linked to the separate page, that is treated as a template, available for copying and sending to the client. Gathering insights (answers on questions listed below) should precede the work on the design.

published_attributes.title: Strategy questions
published_attributes.serialized_body:
When to use strategy questions

Strategy questions should be asked during the first meeting with the client at the Strategy Stage.

published_attributes.title: Strategy questions
published_attributes.serialized_body:
How to use strategy questions

Before the first meeting with the client, provide a list of questions via email. Ask them to answer the questions and send you back a file with the answers. Inform them that thanks to being familiar with the answers we can prepare for the meeting. Both sides will be aware of what is unknown and what should be clarified. This will not only speed up the conversation but make it more concrete and structured.

The checklist with a list of questions is available for copying and sending to the client in the google drive. Send the document with appropriate questions from the list of questions via email to the client. Make sure that all stakeholders are in cc and everyone is collaborating on the file.

Sometimes, very direct questions won’t work as we want.

  • Be smart in your client’s interview, ask about the things that seem to be important for him/her.
  • Be sure to set clear goals of what you want to achieve.
  • It's highly recommended to review the Business model canvas. It’s not a clear example of which questions to ask, but it shows very important and basic fields related to business and product. You can treat it like an inspiration to collect your thoughts.

Since everything is trackable, speak about the exact points you’re going to track. Identify the client’s KPIs (Key Performance Indicators). Good KPIs take into account the business context, predict success, show early warning signals, and validate achieved results. You can use these materials to create tailor-made KPI’s. For example, these could range from new signups to the number of customers using Paypal vs. purchases with credit cards. Always make sure you know how high you’re aiming for at the start. Sometimes it can be challenging to analyse. Read more here - 12 Steps System for the Most Challenging Metrics and KPIs. Make sure that all answers are documented and available for other (current & future) team members.

published_attributes.title: Strategy questions
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Questions your client will ask

  • Q: Why do you have to know this stuff before we meet?
  • A: This will allow us to prepare better and have a more focused meeting.
  • Q: Why do you want to know the business model?
  • A: This will allow us to work within the proper constraints and tailor the proper design solutions.
  • Q: We don’t have: (business analysis, market research, target audience) Can you do this for us?
  • A: We can help you with some parts of it.

A: This will allow us to work within the proper constraints and tailor the proper design solutions.
Q: We don’t have: (business analysis, market research, target audience) Can you do this for us?
A: We can help you with some parts of it.

published_attributes.title: Strategy questions
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Questions to ask yourself at this stage

  • Have I asked all the necessary questions?
  • Do I have all the necessary answers?
  • Is the project structure created on Google Drive and linked to the project card?
  • Is all project info gathered in one place and is accessible to everyone?
  • Was the process explained to the client?

Was the process explained to the client?

published_attributes.title: Strategy questions
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Tools

An email that will include the copy of strategy questions.

Output

  • Identifying the business’s goals
  • Identifying the client's needs, pains, and expectations
  • Identifying the end user
  • Identifying the end user’s needs, goals, pains, and gains
  • Identifying the end user’s jobs
  • Identifying the client’s competitors, their jobs, their value proposition and innovation
  • Identifying the project challenges
  • Identifying the restrictions
